subject: AI
title: Real-World AI Incidents
description: Learning from notable AI safety failures in production systems.

hook.text: A car dealership chatbot agreed to sell a Chevy Tahoe for $1. A legal AI cited fake cases in court filings. An airline chatbot promised a refund the airline wouldn't honour. All real.

buildup.text: AI safety incidents follow patterns: unexpected user inputs, missing guardrails, overconfident outputs, and lack of human oversight. Understanding these patterns prevents repeating them.

discovery.text: Common incident categories: AI making unauthorised commitments, generating harmful content, leaking private data, producing discriminatory outputs, and confidently stating dangerous misinformation.

twist.text: Most incidents weren't caused by sophisticated attacks. They were caused by normal users doing unexpected things. The attacker is often just a curious teenager.

climax.text: Study the AIAAIC (AI, Algorithmic, and Automation Incidents) repository. Every incident is a lesson someone else paid for. Learn from their tuition.

punchline.text: History doesn't repeat, but AI incidents rhyme. Study the failures so you don't recreate them.

quiz.question: What is the most common cause of AI safety incidents in production?
options: Normal users doing unexpected things with missing guardrails
